posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

I'm really shit at video games and I played through it 3-4 times, going all the way down to the bottom of the Iron Maiden and farming Holy Roods and all that.

I really don't get how people struggle with the game. There's only two major gameplay mechanics that are shit easy to "understand".

1. Weapons can't have ALL affinities/strengths at once so you have to maintain 2-3 weapons and switch them up depending on the opponent. You can use the blacksmith's shops to further upgrade them and so on.

2. In the combat the overall idea (past the intro areas) is to use high-risk attacks and chain them to get maximum damage or to simply get to the point you can damage a hardened enemy, then use risk-dissipating methods so you don't soak up damage.

That's literally all there is to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a very good game, with extremely strange mechanics. The problem is that the in-game tutorials are shit, and the mechanics are at times contradictory and counter-intuitive. But it's worth playing for the story, music, and graphics.

Weapons have type, affinities, and class. Learn what these mean from an online guide. Be aware that it'll be impossible to match them up perfectly, and (even if you could) it would be tedious to swap your weapon for every enemy. FYI, type has an outsized role in the damage calculation, affinity is medium, and class is the least. So just focus on type and ignore the others, but you may switch for affinities very rarely if it's a big encounter and you have a great weapon for it.

Read how crafting works online. You MUST craft and you MUST know how combinations work. Drops in chests are shit.

There's an optional dungeon. Get to the end of the first floor and use the item they give you for crafting. It's phenomenal against the final boss.

If you get good stat bonus rolls, stay current with competent crafting, and use the correct type, you'll become OP and finish most end-game boss fights in just a few rounds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522394

You don't need a guide.
The weapon crafting in this game is similar to demon fusion in SMT games.
The game throws a lot of weapons at you through drops/chests and it's up to you to fuse them into better ones.
You can simply go to a blacksmith's shop and try combining random ones to see what you get.
Some combinations give you a similar weapon, some the same but augmented, some a weapon of a higher tier and some a completely different "type". You can easily experiment with all this on your own and figure it out on the go.

The idea is to upgrade your weapons but keep an eye on the stats so certain ones keep improving etc...

>>9522710

Just remember that sometimes the bosses end up simply having a type that you don't have a weapon for and then you might want to brute force them by chaining a lot of abilities or so on.
Also different parts of bosses (head/legs/arms/etc) have different vulnerabilities. It's not usually decisive but it gives you an option to target something else and see if you get better dmg numbers.

A lot of the battles later on involve stacking a lot of high risk chain abilities and then reducing the buildup of risk with items quickly before doing another chain.

>>9525981
It's not monotonous or difficult, if you play in exact the "optimized" way. That is, have 3 weapons (one for each type), and focus only on type. Switch your weapon for the correct type if you're fighting a major enemy only, and otherwise totally ignore attribute and class. Keep PP on weapons max.

Understand that drops in chests aren't weapons you should actually use, but are "raw materials" for crafting. Whenever you can create a better weapon via crafting, do it.

Get good stat rolls and use buffs / debuffs on major enemies.

Done. Now the game is far too easy. I was actually sad during the final boss because I totally broke the game doing this.

posts.com:
Colony Wars 3: This space combat sim is known for its immersive gameplay and engaging storyline, but one of the standout features of the game is its soundtrack. The music, composed by Tim Wright and Jason Page, perfectly captures the mood of each mission and adds to the overall atmosphere of the game. The mix of electronic and orchestral elements creates a unique and exciting audio experience that really enhances the gameplay.

Pro Skater 2: This classic skateboarding game is not only fun to play, but it also boasts a fantastic soundtrack featuring a variety of punk, rock, and hip hop tracks. The music really helps to set the tone for each level and adds to the overall energy of the game.

Jade Cocoon: This role-playing game features a beautiful and atmospheric soundtrack composed by Norihiko Hibino and Atsushi Kitajoh. The music, which blends traditional Japanese instruments with modern electronic elements, perfectly captures the game's setting and adds to the overall sense of mystery and wonder.

Final Fantasy Tactics: This classic tactical RPG features a sweeping and epic soundtrack composed by Hitoshi Sakimoto. The music perfectly captures the mood of each battle and adds to the overall grandeur of the game's story.

Akuji the Heartless: This action-adventure game features a dark and atmospheric soundtrack composed by Ron Fish. The music helps to set the mood for each level and adds to the overall sense of dread and tension in the game. The mix of electronic and orchestral elements creates a unique and immersive audio experience that really enhances the gameplay.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I use a modchip, but I've also been using it since before ODEs and pseudosaturn were a thing. So I'm not sure if it's still the 'best' option. But if you go that route, you'll still want to get a 4-in-1 AR cart for all the other features.

modchip is incredibly easy to install. It's just a small board that goes in-between the connection to the disc drive. The only thing you need to solder is a 5v cable to the power rail. And even that you can even get away with not actually soldering it, and just twisting it tightly around the rail. That's what I did as a "temporary measure" when I was in college and told myself I'd properly solder it in when I got home. That was over a decade ago and I haven't bothered reopening the system because it Just Werks.

posts.com:
>>9523840

Games should be categorized based on the types of technology used, not arbitrary release dates. Look at the way architecture is categorized for example (Classical, Mid-century modern, Postmodern, Neomodern, New Classical, Contemporary, etc…). Mid century modern will never become classical. Similarly, Jazz music will never become classical. Its dumb to call an 8 bit hand held a later gen just because it came out later. The gamegear is literally just a master system. The Wii is literally just an overclocked gamecube and has a weaker CPU & GPU than the Xbox. Using this logic, here's the REAL gaming eras:

Pre-Retro Era:
Gen 1 - Literally just Pong
Gen 2 - Atari 26/52/78, Vectrex, shitboxes nobody cares about

[Insert Gaming Crash Here]

Retro Era AKA The Golden Age:
Gen 3 (8 Bit) - NES, Gameboy, Gameboy Color, Master System, Game Gear, PC 88, MSX, ZX Spectrum, Pico-8, TIC-80
Gen 4 (16 bit) - SNES, GBA, Genesis, PC98, TG16, Amiga, Neo Geo
Gen 4.5 - Sega 32X, 3DO, PC-FX
Gen 5 (32 bit 2D + Low Poly 3D) - PS1, Saturn, N64, DS
Gen 5.5 - Dreamcast, PSP, 3DS
Gen 6 (Mid Poly) - PS2, Gamecube, Wii

[Insert Globohomo Here]

Modern Era (HD widescreen, Microtransactions, Day 1 patches, hyper realism, Casualization, homogenized controllers, homogenized architecture, mocap, facescan, Californian management, etc...):
Gen 6.5 (High Poly, 480p-ish) - Xbox, Vita
Gen 7 (Mainly 720p) - 360, PS3, Wii U,
Gen 7.5 - Switch
Gen 8 (Gen 7 + Stable 1080p) - PS4, Xbone
Gen 8.5 (Gen 7 + 4K) - PS4 Pro, Xbone X
Gen 9 (Gen 7 + 4K + RTX) - PS5, Xbox SX

Agreed. There needs to be a classification centered around tech, because it (very directly) affects the gamut of possible aesthetics and mechanics, and if I might add: I also believe the terminology needs to be different. "Gen" is already meant to be used in a chronological sense. Since this is a valuable take on categorization, I'm convinced there's worth in implementing a different word here. Something like "Wave" would be useful to indicate tech-based classification, plus it fits generally well with the old usage of the word in old games like Klax. How's this?

Pre-Retro Era:
Wave 1 - Literally just Pong
Wave 2 - Atari 26/52/78, Vectrex, shitboxes nobody cares about
(...)
And so on and so forth.

Okay then. Thanks for your time and consideration.

2 is impressive for how much they were able to do with a snes rpg but it’s quite rough around the edges, even compared to other games of that time. The upside is you can get right into the action pretty quickly. If you play it, be sure to use the fan retranslation and maybe the hack that lowers the encounter rate.
3 is great, definitely the best if you stick with it but it takes a very long time for the game to pick up. The first 10-15 hours are basically just a prologue.
4 is memorable for its art style and some of the twists, but, taken as a whole, it’s not quite as good as 3. Also the English release had some content removed but the Japanese version has an English patch.

>>9523335
DOOM came so very close to the first one. They could have given the pistol perfect accuracy and given a damage boost so every shot does the equivalent of two chaingun rounds, this would give it the functionality of a long range sniper weapon but not overpowered. I would also remove the chainguns perfect accuracy of its first two shots. To balance out the shotgun/super shotgun I would make shotgun ammo way more scarce so having to choose between power and conserving ammo is an actual choice, as it stands in the base game I can just unload a super shotgun blast on lone pistol zombie and not care at all.

For the energy weapons I would bump up the BFGs ammo consumption to 75 or 100 per blast because I never felt the need to use the plasma rifle once I had the BFG as the ammo saved was insignificant especially compared the the time to kill difference between the two. Rocket launcher is perfect as is but it always bothered me that rockets were the only weapon type that only had one weapon, I would add a grenade launcher. A flamethrower would also be nice for damage over time, a nice contrast to the BFG where you have to be looking at the enemy to damage them. For a second flame weapon I would add a three round burst fire flaming stake gun whose bullets would stick into the enemy then explode after a few seconds similar to the needler from halo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526138
BFG also is perfectly ammo-efficient on the first shot, dealing exactly 2400 damage for 60 cells (40 per cell). Technically the plasmagun can deal 12, 24, 36, or 48 damage per shot, which averages out to 30 per shot, but you can break it down much more efficiently because one trigger pull is one cell and you don't need to shoot 60 at once. Also if you get lucky you get higher efficiencies, sometimes exceeding the BFG, but not often.
When talking about multiple targets, the BFG loses damage because it splits it damage into groups of 60 (up to 40 projectiles, each dealing Nd60 damage calculated to either kill their target or use up as much of the remaining damage as possible), so anything with health that isn't a multiple of 60 ends up wasting a bit of ammo. Once again, since the PG deals smaller damage per cell good use of it can be more ammo efficient. Definitely can't match the sheer killing speed though.
>math n sheit

Basically the whole cell "economy" is a bit more even for the PG if you aren't trying to explode whole rooms at once. Similar thing with the chaingun where it always hits 15 but the other bullet weapons have slightly different numbers based on role. If you can manage the CG's absurd fire rate you can reach ammo efficiencies that are second only to the pistol's hypothetical max, but it's really inaccurate and you will waste ammo in some cases so it balances out with the SMG which is highly accurate and fires easily controllable bursts.

>>9526138
The alt-fire of the flare gun is super underrated. It's like the equivalent of being able to shoot a rocket out of the doom pistol for 10 ammo. If you come upon a group of enemies let one of those fly, great way to conserve rocket ammo if you're low and you get a similar outcome. Also I think the cultists have a 100% or close to it stun chance if they get hit, so the tommy gun is extremely good against them due to its high fire rate. I remember the plasma gun being great against the hellhounds, was my go to weapon against that enemy type every time.

Blood is a fantastic FPS once you take the time to understand as much as you can about it (like how jumping and crouching makes hitscanners less accurate, or how you should be bouncing explosives around every suspicious corner, they give you tons of dynamite ammo for a reason). I see alot of people give the game a try, get absolutely wrecked by cultists and give up, but if they just knew a little bit more they would be having a total blast. It's sad.

Anyway, hope that taught you how to fish and not be a lazy fuck. It really is just a search away sometimes. It's not programin, it's literally just Vidya game consuming. More often, some retard has had the same problem then you.

You just have to look.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hear me out... This was an experiment, and I think it went well.
I heard the Family Pocket was a fun and convenient device for the money and I thought "bullshit" but tried it because I was looking for cheaper gifts at the time and didn't want to setup and/or build a new device for the 50th time. It's not fun anymore.
I did take out the decoy cartridge and I did throw some other games on to test these silly Java emulators for NeoGeo and SNES, but that's it.
Metal Slug doesn't work. It won't pass the Yoshi's Island test, but I played Earthbound and Mario All Stars fine. Every GBC I've tried ran fine. All the NES and Genesis so far run fine.

It's all setup out of the box with a functioning UI in English, decent lists with boxart, easy save slot for each game, and instant on/off that (so far) seems to be about as safe as possible. I didn't swap the loaded SD for a better one yet so who knows? But six months of testing so far and no worries. I paid $25 for it. It looks and feels like a pickup and play toy and it is. Which I love.

I have several anbernic devices and so on, I'm not a pleb. I'm just sharing my findings on this. It's a really neat convenient affordable toy if you like the proposition.

(Also on a personal note, I love the sound. It isn't good although it has a vol wheel. But the mostly empty softer plastic case seems to smooth out all the bumpy squares and triangles in the sound waves of 8-16 bit games that make my ears thump uncomfortably without a great setup. I have this issue on my 351p with all settings possible tweaked. The smoothing resonance of the cheap case is a nice bonus for me.)
Thank you for liking and subscribing to my autistic review bastard blog

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the breadbin C64 has unreliable, hot-running chips because MOS used an ancient and not very efficient 5-6 micrometer process from the 70s. the VIC-II in particular was quite power-guzzling as it's a very busy chip that has to perform all graphics functions, bus mastering, and RAM refresh, and its internal speed is 8Mhz. after three years of bungled attempts they switched to a modernized lower power 3 micrometer process which is what the C64C chips use.

so combination of some outdated tech and MOS not having especially good engineers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524408
Unfortunately, it's not easily obtainable knowledge, you should know C, you should understand how the compilator processes your code and you should understand the assembly language of a target platform(MIPS in the case of PSX). Tools allow you to decompile an executable file to asm functions with generic names, even convert them to c. But it's not like load exe to Ghidra and getting a working code.

In rare cases, devs forgot the symbol file on a disk so you can obtain names for functions and variables but usually, they don't. So you need to guess names for thousands of functions and variables.

Reverse engineering is a hobby for a high skilled and autistic programmers.

Why does DOS MIDI have such a distinctive tone compared to Windows or General MIDI?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525067
MIDI is not a sound or sample set, it is a protocol by which messages are sent to an instrument to command it what note to play, for what duration, etc. A lot of DOS games were programmed with earlier sound chips in mind that used digital FM synthesis, but the Windows sound set is derived from Roland's MT series library, I believe. Sound cards of the 1990s used ROM to perform higher-quality samples, as opposed to synthesis alone.

>>9526568
>FPS
Unreal Tournament '99, I didn't like FPS games way back then, but it's good ol' UT that made me enjoy the genre. And turned me into an Unreal fanboy.
>VS Fighting
Advanced V.G. 2. This one is thanks to fellow /vr/os, as many anons were talking about the V.G. series and characters in various threads so I decided to give it a shot. The first game is kinda meh SF2 clone, but the second one is very fun, despite still being largely derivative of other games in the genre. And Yuka is the best girl.. I'm gonna try Asuka 120% games next.
>jRPG
Chrono Trigger, along with RPG Maker game called The Way. Never liked most of RPGs, regardless if these are turn-based or action, Japanese or Western, since I used to see them as grindfests for the most part (which is mostly true). CT however has good enough balancing that allows to breeze through the game without grinding at all, plus familiar Toriyama character design (watched Dragon Ball a lot as a kid) and time travelling - that had me sold. And The Way has a ridiculously good story that puts CT and other 16-bit RPGs to shame, though it suffers in terms of gameplay mechanics, still a very enjoyable experience.

Fair enough, but the way some stuff is being shown in Retrotech videos is misleading at best. I'm not saying he's doing it in bad faith, it's just that the way it's sold can induce unecessary panic in people that don't know better. And if they decide to then recap a set based on that, they'll often end up creating a problem rather than fixing one.

I think he has a lot of very useful practical knowledge about fixing CRTs, but he should know when he's out of his depth on technical matters and just flat out tell people: "look, I'm not exactly sure about this but this is what I think is going on" or something along those lines. He clearly lacks knowledge about some of the details of how the electronic circuitry actually works. There's no shame in that, just be honest.

>>9516704
You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518520
Which version you want to play is mostly a matter of graphics. Some think the early release is more atmospheric, others prefer the redrawn versions. See pic related.

Either way, make sure to play a version that has the original still screen gameplay instead of freeroam. The still screens were designed around making things you were supposed to find easily visible, so if you play a freeroam version without having played the original first, it's very easy to miss things that were never meant to be hard to find.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518548
It was extremely significant at the time and is an important point on the timeline of how videogames progressed, so if you're interested in that which the people here who aren't just literally autistic and refuse to play anything they haven't played 1000 times before presumably are it's worth playing just for that reason. It's also a 3D art style that existed in the 90s where fidelity was starting to get to where things are recognizable and nice looking but still very artificial, it gives art like this a dreamlike quality and, at least to me, gives a powerful feeling of what the tech world was like generally back then, I can't look at myst without remembering stuff like the transition from dos to windows, the optimism, just that time period in general and I think that would come through even for someone without memories of that time. It's not a terribly exciting game, but it wasn't back then either. Play it to experience what we considered top of the line art and technology back then, don't expect it to be some kind of thrill lol. It's an adventure game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518585
>extremely significant at the time
Yeah, but it was mainly because CD-ROM craze. It sold in absurd numbers, but was it really that influential, besides spawning a ton of imitators? First person adventure games were nothing new, and neither was environmental storytelling. Without that, Myst only has graphics. I guess you can say that modern walking sims lifted the storytelling tropes from mystoids, but they didn't do it directly - they evolved by themselves from first person horrors like Amnesia and the particular breed of HL mods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518646
It literally pioneered pre-rendered graphics and environmental storytelling. You're going to say no its some other retarded obscure game, but yes, it did. It was a popular game that proved that both concepts could be relevant and it is extremely historically important. The way that Myst told its story, along with the manner the world presents things is a massive precursor to many games that would be released after it.

Also, even till this day, when the art is at its best (e.g. Sirrus's rooms) it is beautifully detailed. FYI, I played Myst for the first time this year, so no, I'm not nostalgiaing over it. The game has great design for its time and is a foray not only into environmental storytelling, but storytelling period in games. Just compare the stories of games that came before Myst and you'll see what I mean.

>>9518520
Myst and Myst Masterpiece Edition are identical in content, but Masterpiece has better audio and color depth compared to the original release. Play Masterpiece Edition if you want less dithering. The only version released after Masterpiece Ed that I can recommend is the first remake, RealMyst (2000), Not to be confused with RealMyst: Masterpiece Edition (2014), or Myst (2020). Realmyst has a lot of minor visual inconsistencies with the original game, but I felt that it preserved the visual tone in realtime 3D better than the sort of tacky 2014 version. I haven't played 2020 Myst, but it doesn't look great, and is and even bigger departure than any of the other remakes.

>>9526672
It was always a tech demo
VF1: just its existence was revolutionary, from the system to the models. Hair and cloth physics, even animated faces.
VF2: texture-mapping
VF3: eye-tracking, more dynamic faces, hair and cloth physics expanded upon, uneven stages and dodge button
VF4: first 3DFG with customization and an online service (arcade only), introduced side-stepping, breakable walls, one stage had a snowy floor and another a watery floor
VF5: Ultimate was done in the Dragon engine, but that's all I remember

The framerate was one of the big improvements that Virtua Fighter 2 made over Virtua Fighter 1. The first game still looked incredible for a 1993 release, but it is still the slowest playing of the Virtua Fighter series. Kinda like how Street Fighter 1 ran at a low framerate. All of the home ports of Virtua Fighter 1 are locked down to 30fps. The 32x game retains 30fps for the majority of the game, but has some slowdown during the win/ lose cutscenes. One of the big enhancements that the model 2 arcade board made was the 60 (57fps) framerate. Every Model 2 arcade game targeted 57fps. Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.

This one has the arcade visuals, but runs at a higher resolution than the arcade game, and also 60fps.

The arcade model 2 board does not run at 60fps due to some sort of limitations of the board. It's really 57fps, but when used with the right type of CRT display, you don't really notice. But 57fps would look janky on LED's, so many of the later VF2 home ports are set to 60 for consistencies sake.

>>9523968
The hardware is deigned like a 2D system what with it's dedicated sprite and background layers, similar to a SNES or a Genesis except more powerfil. Sprites can be arbitrarily scaled, skewed, distorted on all 4 points, allowing devs to do real fake 3D on the Saturn. The background layer is kind of like the SNES, mode 7 effects et-al.

The problem is that due to the sprite nature of the Saturn, you can't really do any advanced 3D effects like reflection mapping due to no real UV mapping support or advanced blending effects.

The PS1 was designed like a real (albeit limited) 3D system from the start with it's hardware accelerated transformation via it's GTE and support for other 3D rendering features.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9524506
Tomb Raider isn't held back by VDP1's fill rate. You can go in and modify the draw commands to draw wireframes instead, which significantly reduces the amount of pixels VDP1 needs to draw and how much fill rate is needed. If you do this however you'll notice the game still chugs and slows down in the exact same spots to the exact same levels of performance. This indicates that VDP1 fillrate is NOT what's causing the performance issues. This means it could either be a CPU bottle neck, memory bottlenecks, etc. Odds are the game just didn't get the final bits of optimization the PS1 port got due to the Saturn port being rushed out sooner.

The other thing to keep in mind is that Sony had their performance analyzer that could tell devs exactly where the bottleneck was in their code and how to fix it. Neither Sega nor Nintendo had anything like that. So that helped developers produce faster code.

So while VDP1's fill rate is lower than the PS1's GPU, it's not the massive performance gap many think it is. Most of these games aren't doing anything that should be getting close to that limit. To hit that limit you need to be doing something really dumb like rendering the entire frame with transparent polygons or not having any code to sort and eliminate non visible polygons.

This is a myth. The PS1 was sold at a similar loss to the Saturn when it launched in 1994 in Japan. This has been revealed by recent interviews from employees involved in both companies. PS1 cost about 50,000 Yen per unit to produce, Saturn cost about 54,800 Yen. Yes Saturn is more, but it's not $100 more. Both systems were sold at a $100 loss as well. The biggest cost issue in both systems wasn't the number of chips, it was the RAM. RAM prices were stupid high during this time and fell dramatically in the next 3 years. What was over $200 worth of RAM in both systems dropped to under $5 worth of RAM in the span of 2-3 years.

People love to point to $399 vs $299 but forget to look at the difference in launch dates. By the time the PS1 launched at $299 Sega had already dropped the Saturn to $349 due to the new VA1 revision and falling RAM prices with it still coming with a game. If you bought a game with your PS1 at launch, you'd be paying the same amount. 2-3 weeks after the PS1 launched Sega released a Saturn that didn't come with a game for $299. By late Spring of 1996 both systems dropped to $199 due to RAM prices continuing to fall dramatically, and in Sega's case more cost reductions with the Model 2 Saturn.

The price wasn't the issue, it was the horrible launch line up in the US.

>>9524640
The Saturn's VDP2 was effectively an entirely separate GPU with dedicated VRAM so a game could offload environments to it and not have to compete with other things for resources in the way the PS1 does.

Something similar happens with visual effects like the water and heat ripples in Mega Man 8 and Mega Man X4. On the Saturn it's a simple VDP2 feature but it's a bit more complicated on PS1 so they just didn't bother. The same way the VDP2 caused problems with transparency layering, it had advantages in other areas.

This is why games were more interesting to compare back then. They were often designed with the system's strengths and weaknesses in mind allowing for more visual diversity. It only became a problem when you started porting shit and suddenly every system looked like a potato. The SNES couldn't handle Genesis ports, either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525101
> it means UP TO 6x, meaning in the worst case scenario, meaning all effects on + transparency, vs no effects on and no transparency.

I literally said that figure applied to rendering transparencies. Gouraud Shading doesn't really have much of a performance hit on VDP1. If you want to know how that figure is actually determined it basically boils down to this.

- A non textured pixel takes about 1 clock cycle to draw.
- A textured pixel takes about 2 cycles to draw.
- A textured and gouraud shaded pixel still takes about 2 cycles to draw.
- A half transparent pixel takes about 6 cycles to draw.

So compared to untextured pixels it's 6 times longer to draw, compared to textured it's 3 times longer to draw. So this is where your up to 6 times longer comes from. So with those values we can say that the max theoretical fillrate of VDP1 is 26-28 Million pixels per second depending on what resolution mode the Saturn is in and if you're drawing all untextured pixels. This is probably how the theoretical value listed earlier was determined. For Textured and Gouraud shaded pixels it's about 13-14 Million pixels per second. For half transparent pixels, it's about 4-5 Million pixels per second.

That's still a pretty significance performance hit for half transparencies. Throw in that they don't work correctly all the time and it's easy to see why most devs went with meshes.

That all said, if you're not doing half transparencies VDP1's fillrate is still more than enough for most games. At 320x240 resolution at 30fps you have enough fillrate to draw the entire frame buffer about 6 times per frame. So if you're sorting and culling polygons properly and not trying to draw everything as half transparent, you really shouldn't be hitting the fillrate limit.

>>9525162
iirc vdp1 requires 1 cycle to prepare a pixel and 1 to write, so nontextured pixel is 2 cycles and textured is 3. half transparency is 6. gouraud shading only increases the per-polygon setup time.

>we can say that the max theoretical fillrate of VDP1 is 26-28 Million pixels per second
26/28 mpixels assumes perfect access of memory on every cycle, not possible because the vdp1 uses sdram, and you have to deal with page miss penalties.

The real peak fillrate is ~24 mpixels peak. early docs flat out state this number. there's at least one homebrew app that measures this same speed on the sh2 side which also uses sdram.

one of the docs gives an actual figure you can use for approximating both texture drawing time, vdp1 per-polygon setup, and page miss penalties. i don't remember the exact values but you could only hit two digit practical fillrates if you did zero effects. with textures, you can barely fill a 320x224 framebuffer twice before you drop out from 60fps.

>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9526373
If you think about the game's concepts less how they're literally incorporated into the game with 1980s FDS software and more the overall game flow and hallmarks, I think Zelda 2 is definitely a precursor to the type of game that would eventually result in Skyrim
Because it's Zelda there are many streamlined elements, but it's still an expansive action RPG featuring a worldwide trek, exploring dungeons and powering up over time until you eventually rule over the once treacherous world thanks to your new weapons and abilities.
Just to tie in some things that are directly shared between Zelda 2 and Skyrim:
>overall game flow of walk around somewhat empty overworld, finding little caves as well as larger ones and dungeons that you either find goodies in or battle through, often beset on the overworld by roaming enemies, visiting towns to rest up and take in lore while making story progress
>both feature EXP and RPG mechanics that provide the player with plenty of opportunity throughout the game to customize their loadout and decide which stats they'd like to specialize in
>although Zelda 2 lacks most economy and loot systems due to streamlining, its palaces are still quite similar to plenty of Skyrim dungeon areas with many monsters to fight as you comb through the rooms looking for the reward (the ability to place the crystal and level up instantly in the case of Zelda 2)
This is just scratching the surface, basically just pointing out the most obvious shit. I could go on but my point is that Zelda 2's flow reminds me of the type of thing you'd see in many action RPGs to come. It's a game that feels ahead of its time in my opinion for combining those aspects of gameplay in the way it did.

>>9516995
>AI's getting better, soon we won't need to learn Japanese,
It's really not. It appears like it is because the end result is usually correct English, but the quality of the translation itself is still really really bad. I have to translate some stuff from Japanese to English for my work before the new year rolls around (I'm not a translator, but I'm the only person in the company who is bilingual enough to do translation so I sometimes get stuck translating stuff) and I thought I could cheese it and run everything through DeepL since it's all super straightforward and grammatically correct with no slang or anything. Simple business language. Fucking nope, errors everywhere and I ended up having to actually translate it all myself. I was really disappointed because I was hoping that I could finish early with machine translation and then read a book or something but I'm pretty sure my ass would be in hot water if I turned in what DeepL gave me.

Btw, a ton of official translations (fan and official) are done by machines these days and that's a big part of why they're so bad, because machine translation is awful and the actual "translator" doesn't actually know the language so they're incapable of catching the mistakes when they happen.

Anyone who is actually fluent in Japanese and English would know that machine translation still has an extremely long way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As someone who's followed the fan translation scene since the late '90s, which were focused on very well known titles (in those circles at the time) that just never made it overseas, like FFV and Star Ocean (the latter of which was hilariously controversial especially because DeJap blueballed everyone by claiming the lead translator's HD blew up back in 2001 or 2002 and asked for money lmao), I don't believe learning Japanese just to play video games is worth it especially in this day and age, mostly for a number of reasons.

Unless you specifically consume only Japanese media daily and use it proactively, you're not going to truly learn and comprehend the language and cultural history behind it, especially one that's so wildly different from English. That's not even getting into issues like nonsensical location jokes and references / skits that are extremely dated. There are lots of translators today, both by people who do it for a living or for fun or even AI / MTLs are getting in on the action, all of which pretty much renders that original "worth learning" part moot. On top of that, that's not even getting into the nightmare of localizations and the script purity question. Even with all of those compounded factors, there are people who still pushed through with it and there's a ton more people who know Japanese now than there was a decade or two ago, leaving a very saturated field of translators who are constantly fighting over rights to translate. There's also another thing in this thread that's worth pointing out too: most of the titles posted are either Sega Saturn, obscure PC-E or PS1/PS2 titles, the reason which is that the technology to actually inject and rewrite text, make sure it fits the boxes, etc. is a much more difficult task than translating the script itself wholesale. This is not even a new thing either, since you can find entire script translations on GameFaqs from the 90s and 00s long before the games even had working translation patches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523219
Linda Cube Again and Linda Cube Kanzenban are fifth gen remakes of the PC Engine CD title Linda Cube. A "psycho thriller and hunting RPG," protagonist Ken Challenger is chosen, along with his slightly crazy but devoted tomboy girlfriend Linda, to collect one male and one female of every species of animal on the planet of Neo-Kenya and upload them into a massive space ark before a giant meteorite destroys the planet and everything left on it in seven in-game years. As time passes, the weather and seasons change, and various animals and NPCs will only come out during certain conditions. The game features several novel systems, including dog party members which cannot be directly controlled. It also features three unique story scenarios which represent adjoined worlds and excellent art design from Japanese artist Cannabis. The first two scenarios are very violent and dramatic and the third is a joke scenario where everyone gets a happy ending.

>>9523268
Daikoukai Jidai 2 AKA Uncharted Waters: New Horizons, is a fifth gen remake of the cult classic Koei game, a pseudo-historical swashbuckling RPG which takes place during the Age of Exploration. Players can choose to play one of 6 different protagonists which feature different gameplay styles and intertwining storylines. The game has updated graphics and sound compared to the original console releases, which were also sadly censored when initially released in the West. It has an excellent score by Yoko Kanno and an unprecedented amount of freedom in how you approach playing the game, where the world map is a map of the original world.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9523320
Daikoukai Jidai Gaiden is a direct sequel/spinoff to Uncharted Waters: New Horizons. It only features two protagonists, allegedly so that they could go further in-depth with the storylines. It features extensive cameos from the original cast. One of the protagonists, Salvador, is the son of Khayr Ad-Din, AKA Redbeard, king of the corsairs and a major antagonist in the first game. His storyline gets much darker than those of the six protagonists in part two. The game features updated an updated tide and weather system which is meant to be more accurate than the previous game. Islamic regions will also not let you pray in their churches anymore, and Chinese ports are closed off to outsiders in an attempt to be more historically accurate. The coverart is by some famous furfag.

Cyber Doll is a yellow label (soft 18+) RPG for the Sega Saturn. Humans begin to fall apart and are forced to become cyborgs if they want to live. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anyway, 4116 RAM was found in (among other things)

>Apple II/II+
>Commodore PETs excepting the original chicklet key model
>TRS-80 Model I/II/III
>Atari 400/800/5200
>Colecovision
>the first IBM PCs with the 16k-64k motherboard

This stuff had three power lines (+12V, +5V, and -5V). The -5V line is used for bias and it has to always be the first to activate at power on and last to deactivate at power off. If you lose it, the chips form internal parasitic diodes and go up in smoke. This means anything with 4116 RAM was very vulnerable to PSU fails. Like mentioned above, you can modify boards to accept newer and much more reliable single voltage RAM.

Yeah, when they’re done well.

Inserting cartoon characters into an already well-established and popular aesthetic (in this case basketball/hip hop) works because it doesn’t break the layer of irony that comes with it. In the case of those Looney Tunes, it’s “cool” because it’s kind of funny.

Whereas with this shit >>9525010, it’s Mickey Mouse trying WAY too hard to look cute in an edgy, almost emo sort of way. The aesthetic itself is NOT well-established so we as the viewer have no idea what he’s trying to pull off with that pose and that outfit. It actually, literally begs the question
>what the fuck did he mean by this?

We can’t feasibly see this as funny, because it’s evident that Mickey is 100% serious about looking like he belongs in a fucking boyband. There is no layer of irony to it, and that is what makes it awkward and uncool.

KH1 has got the most perfect pacing when it comes to gameplay progression and powercreep

Sora starts with very simple movement and his attacks are very simple, by the end once you face off the extra bosses you really feel like you have grown as a character specially if you craft all end game weapons for all 3, many games fail at recreating this feel and it's very rewarding

Also I do agree with posts above, end game Sora in KH1 feels very balanced compared to end game Sora in KH2

Having said that though I think I like KH2 for completely different reasons, it being a pseudo Devil May Cry with JRPG elements being one of them, also KH2 is more "anime" than KH1 because of all the 1v1 fights and all the cool shit Nomura included in many of the bosses and general gameplay

Really wished the gameplay would have remained good because Square had something great going on before they killed the franchise with BBS (I also like this entry though but modern KH is nothing like what KH1 and KH2 used to be)

I was 10 when this came out. This shit was mindblowing to a kid. I grew up with Disney cartoons and FF7 was one of the first games I had on PS1. The commercial with simple and clean would play all the time. Yeah this shit was dope, what a time to be alive.
Thankfully I wasn’t super autistic, but the wave of autism this caused at some kids in school was immense (I am thinking about one annoying retard in particular).
Sequel was good too but wasn’t nearly as magical, mostly liked it for Tron world.

My favorite thing about this game was how it starts you off on this ethereal comfy island with all your friends (who are kid versions of characters from final fantasy games you already played) and then it transports you to fucking Disney animated universe with movies you already watched. It was so weird and interesting, and I really like how they did the 2D Disney cartoons in 3D without losing much in translation.
Embarrassing to admit to liking something so autistic but holy shit this was a drug to a child in 2002.
It lives and dies by its incredible opening, that tropical island as your door to a new universe was expertly done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9518587
I'd make this top 10
1. Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow—must play for everyone. If you pick just 1 game, make it this one.
2. Rhythm Tengoku—best rhythm game I've played. Play if you like quirky games like Wario Ware and rhythm games.
3. Advance Wars—personally not a fan, but those who liked it spent hundreds of hours in it. Very addictive strategy game.
4. WarioWare—quirky and addictive, one of the more original games for GBA. If you've never tried it, do. If you did, still fun to see where it all started from.
5. Metroid Fusion—it's 2D Metroid, enough said. It's great despite some say it's not Super Metroid.
6. Mother 3—not a perfect RPG, but one many people want to play now. Play if you like Earthbound or want an RPG with plot.
7. Wario Land 4—some praise this is as pinnacle of GBA or even best platformer ever, others will write it off as good but ultimately weaker than the GBC ones. Regardless, well worth a try.
8. Mario & Luigi—actually very good RPG, only brought down by bing bang wahoo style and kinda whatever graphics.
9. Kirbies in general—always fun and worth a play. Play if you like Kirby, don't play if you're sick of platformers.
10. Mega Man Zero 3 & 4—decent games, but got pretty overrated recently as some "official canon classics". I beat them all, they're fun and good but not really masterpieces. Play if you like Mega Man X series and / or have played the other 9 games already.
Not on the list:
SNES ports, especially Mario ports—kind of obsolete in current day and age, maybe save for SMW as you can collect dragon coins in it, but that's it.
Pokemons—you either love them or hate them. If you love them, you probably know which ones to play anyway, and may prefer remakes.
Zelda: Minish Cap—it's more Zelda. Play it or skip it, it's alright if you want more ALTTP but thats about it.
Treasure games—no comment.
Mega Man Battle Network—one of those monster / card collect series that just goes on and on.

>>9525731
Facts about this pin:
Best selling pinball machine of all time. Sold 21070 units.
There was going to be an N64 game from Digital Eclipse that recreated this pinball machine, but it was cancelled in an early stage of development.
Pat Lawlor, this game's designer, retired just this year. His last game, which also came out earlier this year, was Toy Story 4 from Jersey Jack Pinball which sold out quite fast, ending his career on a high note.
The Weather Machine topper you see on top of a lot of Addams Family pins derives from a deleted scene from the movie. Of course, Williams didn't know the scene wasn't going to make the final cut of the movie when they built the topper.
There was a pinball machine based on the Munsters TV show released in 2019.
One of Pat Lawlor's early ideas for the design involved a dollhouse-type diorama in the backbox which would light up and do stuff.

posts.com:
The Addams Family games are okay.
Fester's Quest on NES is flawed, lot of bad decisions, and it could have been a better game, but as it is, it's alright. There's probably a romhack that patches a lot of the troubles the game has away, but even without it, it can be fun to play.
Addams Family and Pugsley's Quest on SNES are really great games. There's a lot to explore, loads of little secrets, and the sidescrolling is top notch.
Addams Family Value on SNES is an alright ALttP clone, but I personally didn't care for it.
Didn't play any of the other ones.

>>9526145
I don't find the challenge provided by platforming to be very interesting. Challenging combat sections are interesting because you have options, you can change up your approach or what sub-weapon you want to use at that point in the game (depending on availability) and you can play more or less aggressively depending on your health. Platforming is either you press a button at the right time or you don't. Punishing that failure with death makes the game more challenging, yes, but it doesn't make it any more interesting or fun. In fact, it can make it more boring.

Compare phase one of Dracula in X to phase one in Rondo, for example. The fact that the Dracula X fight is full of instant-kill death pits means that the smartest approach is to camp in one spot and move as minimally as possible. That means you spend a good chunk of the fight sitting twiddling your thumbs waiting for Dracula to show up, and no matter how much health you have, or how much health Dracula's at, it's never safe to get more aggressive and jump around looking for him because the pits kill you instantly. Is it harder than the Rondo Dracula fight? Absolutely. Is it more boring? Absolutely.

Playing aggressively during the first phase doesn't pay because Dracula's spawn points are completely random. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523667
>NEC was nickel-and-diming
Both the initial CD launch and the Duo were totally reasonable. The price of RAM back in those days was killer, the super system card was really only for the early adopters, everyone else got a Duo which was cheaper than the Mega CD at launch because Sega were retards and put in extra RAM for no good reason.

Everyone did the AV cable shit, the 6 button controller worked on like 2 games, multitap is the only arguable piece of bullshit. Well, that and the SuperGrafx.

The PC-FX put all its eggs in the FMV basket after NEC got constant complaints from its retarded devs about how they had to use fantastic looking sprites due to memory and CPU limitations instead of lazy poorly compressed animated video. They also wanted to do the same thing they did with the PCE, get in early, establish a consumer base, and then upgrade the system to compete. The problem is that they didn't have any games ready in 1992 when the system should've launched, because everyone was still working on the PCE. So it got pushed back to 94, where it looked like SHIT. The PS1 came out first. The PCE looked good on launch, and even better a year later when they had CD and the Mega Drive couldn't compete.

>>9512063
I'm actually of the opinion that visual novels are better if Japanese isn't your first language.
I've read plenty of English visual novels and the experience can be somewhat unengaging, and they certainly don't feel like video games.
Reading a Japanese VN is much more involved. Looking up words, trying to learn them, and untangling sentences with twisted spaghetti grammar is quite stimulating. It honestly feels like playing a good puzzle game.
Like most puzzle games it can be really frustrating sometimesー I remember nearly pulling my hair out trying to figure out what the fuck 々 meant without knowing how to type or pronounce it. But overall it's mostly fair and mostly fun.
The extra time you spend with the story from your slow reading speed helps you get invested, and all the extra challenges you had to overcome really makes it feel earned when the cute anime girl you've fallen in love with tells you she loves you too.
In any case, ToHeart2 is an interesting title to look into even if you usually couldn't care less about visual novels. The PC version (XRATED) comes with a versus puzzle game and a shooting game, and the third entry Manaka de Ikuno!! comes with a trading card game and a full RPG. They're a lot of fun; it makes me wish more VNs had minigames.
If anyone here is interested in trying out XRATED, make sure you get the latest update, it adds a new character to the puzzle game.

>>9507519
I think this website alone proves that people who are against achievements in video games simply lack skill.

It was only when they were first introduced in the PS3 / 360 era that cheevos sucked. The go-to example of this is probably The First Templar (way too easy) or Gran Turismo 5 (requires a retarded amount of dedication) not to mention all of the online-only trophies which were functionally impossible to get.

Nowadays, while there are a lot of games releasing solely for trophy hunters to get an easy platinum, most other achievement lists are designed by the developers themselves rather than a third party. In my opinion, if retro devs had access to cheevo software back in the day, the lists they would have made might be quite similar to these fanmade ones - barring glitches and 1cc autism, of course.

My go-to pick for proof of why RetroAchievements is fantastic are the coin challenges in SMB1. Even when you consult a level map to get every coin possible, ratchet scrolling means you have to be basically perfect. There's also the ironman challenge for SMW, or the extra hard cheevos for F-Zero X. It's also worth mentioning that the API's implementation is a fantastic training tool for indie devs since you have to dive deep into the code and tinker with lots of stuff just to make a functioning trophy.

There are definitely games which don't need achievements at all. Like, no one is ever going to fucking care you got 100% in NES Bubble Bobble. I still believe that it's a necessary step towards helping the younger generation get into older games. I hated Balloon Fight and Clu Clu Land until I tried getting cheevos for them, and it showed me that in spite of their lack of content these games can be enjoyed for an insane amount of time if you're going for specific challenges.

Animation, sound, art design, level design/variety are all top-notch. Boss design is great and plenty of enemy variety. Primary and secondary weapons are well-balanced and there is a trade-off between more firepower vs. higher rank.

What I really love though is the slower, more deliberate approach to the game. I think that's what a lot of people struggle with, this is a game where you are really meant to proceed with caution and really take advantage of the fact that the game doesn't autoscroll. Every time you play, you get a bit more efficiency, a bit better method to approach a section, and can better parse the vast amount of information that is thrown at you at once. And then when you start to get really good, you can do speed strats (unfortunately there is no scoring incentive, but still fun). It's definitely a game that grows on you.

Haven't needed to solder anything in a while since I basically completed everything I needed to do. Recapped a few old consoles that were malfunctioning or experiencing issues like audio hum. Did an RGB mod for my N64. Made an entire set of my own RGB cables for everything I needed, etc.

Most proud of actually successfully doing the NESRGB installation, something I had been putting off for a while beforehand. I don't have a desoldering gun but by some miracle I was able to take out the PPU without damaging the fucker. I also desoldered/disassembled the power/RF-modulator daughterboard, took out the RF circuitry, and repurposed the hole for the RGB mini-din port, as well as repurposing the channel select switch to now turn the NESRGB on/off.

Maybe at some future point I'll recap my spare 24" trinitron. It has some weird geometry issues and the red values can't ever get quite right, and slowly creep up or down depending on the drive setting. I assume it's a capacitor issue somewhere.

Post for blog contribution to the board: I tried to solder a new battery onto a copy of Smash Bros 64, since the unlocked content / stats would reset everytime the power went off and I figured it was the problem. I have only the vaguest memories of soldering from back when a took an intro electronics class in high school (not recent).
It still doesn't save anything when the N64 powers down, so I don't know if I messed up the soldering or if the problem was actually do to some other fault on the board (seems unlikely though). I didn't have access to flux, or any kind of solder sucker/remover (never used one in high school and didn't know it existed) so I basically just melted a bunch of solder over the new battery terminals and hoped for the best. This was a few months back, so I can't recall if I used a multimeter to confirm the battery connection was good or not.
I'm not sure if if it's worth investing in some sort of additional soldering tools, or even what they would be, and practicing my skills since at the moment it's my only piece of electronics that I might have to repair. I'll be annoyed if I buy two new pieces of gear, re-solder the new battery (admittedly it's a fast process), and then find out the game STILL doesn't work correctly. It just seems like a lot of learning and shopping for a fix that might not work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523926
Took forever. Lots of fucking around with one of those dogshit solder suckers and wick. But there were still a few pins that connect to a large ground plain that I just couldnt get free.

I ended up getting it out with a fucking heat gun. I put the board chip-side down against an iron 45lb plate with the PPU over the center hole. I covered the motherboard with several layers of aluminum foil so that only the PPU pins were exposed. Then I heater it up a bit at a time and started tuggging on the PPU from the bottom underneath the iron plate until eventually I tugged it free

I was so scared that I probably just fried the chip... but it worked. Still going strong to this day

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9520838
Here's a good example from the second game. A door opens up and there's an axe-throwing zombie in front, a weak zombie to his right, and a strong zombie behind that one. You've got two ways you can go about this: You can either start by killing the axe-thrower then try to carve through the strong zombie and weaker zombie guarding him before they reach you. Or you can ignore the axe thrower and prioritize getting rid of the stronger zombie. The later method eliminates any threat of the strong zombie reaching you, but it requires having to shoot down an axe projectile while you're doing it.

That's not even getting into stuff like score items that often have a small window to collect in the middle of a zombie attack.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's this quirk with Megaman 4-6 where the charging sound won't play under certain conditions, like, if the channel is busy playing something else at the moment when the charging sound should start playing. You can achieve this for example, by letting go of a charge then pressing the button again right after, if you time and aim it right, you'll start charging when the channel is busy playing the hit/explosion sound and you'll get a silent charge that lasts until you let go. Lately when I do buster only replays of those games I try to time my shots to get silent charges as much as I can, so I can enjoy the music more. It's a fun little diversion from just playing the regular way.

I believe the channel also gets muted during screen transitions so you can time it with those too? I don't know all the details to be honest, but I wonder if any of those autists that like to dissect game code have ever figured out the exact conditions during which this happens, would be fun to know.

>>9520615
Not who you're replying to, but beyond its greater damage output, the charge shot also has a wider hitbox (after MM4) and doesn't allow you to fire any lemons until it leaves the screen. As such, there are more than a few situations where not starting off with a charge shot is the better play:
>Groups of weak, vertically-stacked enemies
>Bosses with unpredictable vertical movement (laying down a 'spread' of lemons gives you better odds of hitting them)
>Enemies with small weak points
>Enemies that have to be 'revealed' (like the barrels from MM6) before becoming vulnerable
>Enemies that you have to repel by firing shots at their invulnerable points (think the gorilla midboss from MM6)

The main issue here is that several games in the series deliberately avoid these kinds of situations, instead promoting gameplay where the charge shot is always the ideal option. MM5 is particularly bad about this - almost every stage includes low-lying enemies that can only be hit with charge shots, and the stage layout gives you ample time to prepare shots in between enemy waves.

>>9526520

The main issue with Fire Emblem games is that they seem to be tactical rpgs, but are actually tactical puzzle games.
There is usually a "trick" to the level/map where you're supposed to play it a very specific way in order to obtain items/characters/goals.
So you go in thinking you can kind of freestyle it but the game essentially forces you into a very narrow approach.

Because of that I find it fundamentally different from lets say Tactics Ogre or FFT, where the flow of battle can fluctuate, characters can be rez'd and you have more flexibility overall.

>>9517445
I have only played Origins and Shattered Memories and didn't really like either.

Origins:
Pros:
>decent attempt to recapture the feel of the originals
>good atmosphere in a few areas, keeps use of fixed camera angles but they're awkward in a few areas
>brings back outdoor exploration from SH1
>good ost, as expected from Yamaoka
Cons:
>over emphasis on physical combat, made way more annoying then it needs to be because weapons have durability and you can carry unlimited weapons, so if you want a specific weapon you literally have to menu across dozens of weapons you picked up before it
>core mechanic is you can enter and leave the otherworld whenever you wish, this leads to a lot of samey "explore normal world, enter otherworld and interact with something, go back and use the change to the real world to progress" situations. Also it just makes the existence of otherworld in general less memorable
>story is pretty terrible. The game simultaneously tries to do a retread of the lore seen in SH1 and have the protagonist experience his own SH2 journey of self realization and neither comes close to being good. The SH1 characters act nothing like they did in the original making their motives and dialogue awkward and Travis' own story is both very generic and not even executed well
Overall a 6/10, just above average to be notable I would say but lacks the memorable aspects of prior games. as a lorefag the way they recontextualize so many aspects of SH1, from the cast to the lore, really annoys the fuck out of me but that's a more personal problem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517721
Shattered Memories:
Pros:
>looks great for a wii game, environments are well detailed and character models look mostly okay beside the faces I would say
>Yamaoka's last game for the series, not his greatest work but there's still some great tracks here
Cons:
>combat has been removed entirely, you have no means to defend yourself to any capacity. This could have been interesting if executed better but then this leads into the next major issue
>enemies only appear in scripted chase sequences. Not only do you spend most of the game with no tension since there's no danger, but even when enemies appear all you do is easily run away from them
>puzzles are terrible. A lot of them try too hard to incorporate the wiimote and feel more like playing some kind of dumb minigame then a thoughtful puzzle you have to think about
>exploration is weak, with no danger normally it's just you traversing linear layouts with little to do
>the "scares" are just from listening to voice messages of teenagers being retarded and putting themselves in dumb situations, they're not scary or even entertaining
>the game big appeal, the way it "psychoanalyzes" you, feels very cheap and literally punishes you for looking at things across the game. What you look at determines what kind of person your Harry is and you basically have "decent human being" and varying levels of him being a shitty person.
4/10. A lot of people seem to quite like this one and I just don't get it. It's not only essentially a walking sim, but a walking sim that punishes you for exploring by changing whatever outcome you may desire. I really don't get what people see in it but still recommend it, maybe you could get something more out of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9523318
Anon, you got it all wrong.

The original project, Room 302, was always intended to be connected to Silent Hill. It more seems like the connections were going to be very loose though, rather then tie into previous games through the use of elements like Walter and the cult. The real reason it came out wonky was because after SH2 Konami forced Team Silent to develope both SH3 and SH4 simaltaneously. Because if this Team Silent essentially split into two teams, a lot of the more key members went to work on SH3 while the sort of "B-Team" of Team Silent did SH4. A lot of people who did smaller roles in SH1/2 were forced into majpr positions with SH4, resulting in the muddled execution.

In most video games for the Olympics, football/soccer, and team sports in general, were usually left out, with the main exception I can think of being... the Mario & Sonic franchise. 2020 was probably the best year in that regard, both Mario & Sonic at Tokyo 2020 and the official Tokyo 2020 video game feature football/soccer, and both have better turfs and lighting than eFootball still, which is sort of funny.

When it comes to video games that are 100% made with Olympic football/soccer in mind I can only think of Olympic Soccer 1996 and Winning Eleven 2000, with the latter actually being incredible to me.

I wish that we'd get these stand alone adaptations again, or maybe that the official Paris 2024 video game actually gives the sport more care and adds the official players and nations, anything but a bare bones DLC for EA Sports FC or eFootball that'll just be lost in time eventually, I want to be able to go back to a tournament like I can go back to any FIFA World Cup before 2018, when it became a DLC.

posts.com:
>>9525986
Most Rockstar games are these sequences of arbitrary, barely playable one-off tasks that are ridiculous enough to be entertaining on paper but not too ridiculous for the setting. That's not a dumb way to design your realistic sandbox when missions have good flow and presentation that naturally weave you into these tasks, but that's not what Bully does or even can do. The world doesn't make up for the bad gameplay but is completely dead and eventless until you get to the point where your task or minigame happens, which is either frustrating or way too easy and not worth exercising more than your bare minimum for because you know it's just another cheap one-off thing. They clearly didn't respect the setting of their own game and knew just throwing the GTA principle at a boarding school would be enough for the media and journalists to make it sell. Not even asking for a proper morality system or good NPC AI, but, contrary to what the title promises, you can't even live out your inner bully in this game or do anything too evil

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9517751
Unmodded Oblivion is dogshit from a gameplay perspective, anyone who tries to argue otherwise has either not played past level 20 or has not touched the game in 15 years. Barely any feedback compared to the meaty thwack and stagger animations in Morrowind, and bloated HP pools to offset hit chance being removed means you end up with monotonous 5 minute slap fights every two or three minutes. Aggressive level scaling on everything will either have you tearing you hair out trying to keep an edge against enemies in the next bracket ahead of you or constantly throttling the difficulty slider up and down to just be able to play the game without getting reamed by the hundreds of ogres and minotaurs that will eventually spawn in the wilderness. Individual quest premises are usually fun or entertaining, but most of them are not very well realized, and the big quest lines easily have some of the lamest writing and design in the game. The voice acting, endearingly shit NPC AI, and overall comfy atmosphere are Oblivion's saving graces, and I suspect they're the primary reason more people aren't harsher when evaluating it. It really does feel like Bizarro Morrowind sometimes, since almost every issue someone may have with Morrowind is """""fixed""""" by Oblivion, but every problem with Oblivion has a design-level solution that already existed in Morrowind.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9517761
>What about link cable support on GB/C/A games? Can you demonstrate this feature while paired with an original console? No!

For the GB/GBC, yes. The cores support it over the SNAC connection and there are SNAC cables for it.

For GBA currently no, the core does not support it yet, but the hardware is capable if the core got updated to support it.

>What about utilizing custom chips on cartridges to expand features on consoles?

It currently supports every expansion chip except those two SNES Mahjong games that had ARM co-processors on them. It even supports the SPC-7110 games, something not even SNES flashcarts support, and the homebrew "custom" SNES expansion chips like the MSU-1 or the additional custom hardware in the Atari 7800 version of Rikki and Vikki, of which only a single software emulator is able to run.... and only because the developer of the game made that emulator specifically to run his game on PCs.

>>9521590
Input lag can definitely be a perceptible problem, but there's both people who dramatically oversell its existence, prominence, and impact, as well as those trying to pretend that it's actually nothing.
In truth, input lag can vary widely for a very large amount of different reasons, given how different games work differently, different displays work differently, and different software emulators and hardware emulators differ amongst each other as well as original hardware, along with potential settings, there's hundreds of variables determining what kind of input lag you can be looking at. In many cases it truly isn't perceptible, others may be subtly perceptible, and some where it has an appreciable impact on the player's experience without them having to be a turbo-autistic speedrunner who can do arbitrary code execution in their sleep.
It's cumulative.

https://youtu.be/b3tbcUszA2s?t=515

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521525
You're right, I can get used to it, but why would when there are solutions for mitigating it and in other cases completely eliminating it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9521749
I appreciate what the section of the video you linked demonstrates which justifies some of my own research and adds merit to what people have taught me from different retro gaming communities. This is why I am really interested in the MiSTer and frequently visit my locals to play the one they set up since I can't afford my own yet. The FPGA itself doesn't have any lag; and disregarding how accurate the core is, so the program gets sent out as is. Further down the pipeline is where the potential accumulative lag begins to be introduced.

>Input Device
You can either use the direct serial port to interface original hardware via SNAC. Direct serial has no inherent lag, but even an OEM controller might have some, yet not enough that you won't notice. USB on the other hand has to translate your inputs at the OS level which might add delay but nowhere near half a frame so it is up to you to choose a device that has an encoder with the least amount of delay.

see:
MiSTer Input Latency Database [full detailed sheet linked on the page]
https://rpubs.com/misteraddons/inputlatency

>Game itself
Some games have a different kind of delay due to how the programmer affixed the sprite flow and input command as well as other underlying programming variables which might cause undesirable performance. Some of these inconsistencies can be fixed or changed by the community as needed.

>Display
In my opinion, playing over a CRT display is the optimal way to play the MiSTer. There are plenty of options that will suit people of all budgets. As for digital displays, you have an abundance of choice and you will get the best results with a "gaming" monitor designed to provide the least amount of lag.

Or, you can just buy each console you want to play for peace of mind that you are experiencing the game as originally intended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525380
>Who is the target audience for the mister?
The mistake a lot of people make is that they view the MiSTer FPGA project like a commercial product (i.e Analogue) when in fact it's just an enthusiast venture. The only people making immediate profit off of the project are the people selling pre-built add-ons for the DE-10 Nano to be used with the MiSTer FPGA project, and of course Terasic for each DE-10 Nano unit sold. Sorg, the main developer, is not directly profiting off this project, but he does accept donations which is a huge difference from providing services for pay. Some add-on sellers do state on their website that a portion of each sale will be donated to Sorg so this kind of transparency shows which sellers we should be buying from as well if you don't plan to build your own add-ons.

Most vocal people in the "just emulate for free" category don't actually provide any solid arguments or convincing points to add weight to their posts so I would prefer to disregard them.

There is a surprising amount of people in the MiSTer FPGA community who already have hardware collections and are convinced they can sell parts of their collections with no regrets. The biggest contributing factors to why most haven't pulled the trigger is sentimental value as well as trying to hold on for huge returns in the collector's market. As for people who do have hardware collections plus a CRT and aren't interested in the MiSTer, they are fine where they are because they are not in search of a solution to replicate what they can already do now.

>Has anyone tried out the AO486 core?
It's in the middleground between setting up real hardware and virtual machines as far as involvement goes, but it's a lot closer to setting up a virtual machine. I have not used external accessories besides mouse and keyboard, but I believe it does support Real-Time Clock and definitely MIDI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9522219
I don't get the appeal of focusing so much on numbers, to me it's all about the experience of playing most of all really, but to each their own I suppose, so here are my recommendations for you, OP...

1. QuackShot (Sega Genesis): It's not a complete piece of cake, but it's really enjoyable and well made, short and has unlimited continues, so as long as you keep going it should be a matter of time.

2. World Cup Italia '90 (Sega Genesis): I'm not sure if you're into football/soccer, but this is a simple one, a tournament of 7 matches, just spam diagnoal long balls and try to do a header or bicycle kick.

3. Sonic Chaos (Sega Master System/Sega Game Gear): I'd say this is the easiest 2D Sonic platformer ever made, just keep going to the right and you'll beat it, if you want 100% completion though...

4. Lucky Dime Caper & Deep Duck Trouble (Sega Master System/Sega Game Gear): A similar situation to QuackShot, they're both good, fun and short, with unlimited continues, just keep playing them.

5. World Cup Italia '90 (Sega Master System): Another 7 match tournament, just select a good team like Brazil, run up the pitch or do long passes, and score by passing it sideways near the box.

6. Donald Duck no Mahou no Boushi (SNES): A straightforward adventure even on the hardest difficulty setting, same situation as the previous Donald Duck titles I've mentioned, and a good time too.

7. Crash XS & Crash 2 (GBA): Lovely adaptations of Crash's PS1 gameplay into 2D, completing them 100% isn't so simple, but just getting to the end should give you much trouble at all, both are a good time.

I hope I was able to help out, OP. I'd say there are lots of titles you could try, but there's are just the ones that came up to my head for some reason, hope that you can beat them, but most of all, have fun doing it.

>>9523212
I think it depends on what kind of household you grew up in. In my home games were an occasional treat. My dad hated when I got more of them. I grew up not knowing that buying used games was even a thing. So of course I didn't get guide books or magazines either. I would just play games until I got too bored or frustrated to continue. Completing levels felt great but beating the game was not the objective, the objective was to have fun and keep that going.

I never saw the ending to SMB1 and didn't feel it was important to see one. After all, cartoons don't end, they just keep having episodes after episodes, so why should a game have to end? That's bad.
